review.title: Lower Bound Bayesian Networks - An Efficient Inference of Lower Bounds on Probability Distributions in Bayesian Networks
review.abstract: We present a new method to propagate lower bounds on conditional probability distributions in conventional Bayesian networks. Our method guarantees to provide outer approximations of the exact lower bounds. A key advantage is that we can use any available algorithms and tools for Bayesian networks in order to represent and infer lower bounds. This new method yields results that are provable exact for trees with binary variables, and results which are competitive to existing approximations in credal networks for all other network structures. Our method is not limited to a specific kind of network structure. Basically, it is also not restricted to a specific kind of inference, but we restrict our analysis to prognostic inference in this article. The computational complexity is superior to that of other existing approaches.

metadata.title: Lower Bound Bayesian Networks – An Efficient Inference of Lower Bounds on Probability Distributions in Bayesian Networks

sections.text: We present a new method for propagating lower boundaries of conditional probability distributions in conventional Bayesian networks. Our method ensures that we provide outer approximations of the exact lower boundaries. A key advantage is that we can use all available algorithms and tools for Bayesian networks to represent and derive lower boundaries. This new method delivers results that are accurately detectable for trees with binary variables, and results that compete with existing approaches in credal networks for all other network structures. Our method is not limited to a particular type of network structure, nor is it limited to a particular type of conclusion, but we limit our analysis in this article to prognostic conclusions.

sections.text: At present, the most important means of displaying and propagating lower and upper probability limits in Bayesian networks are faith networks, generalizing the concept of Bayesian networks by propagating convex sets of discrete probability distributions instead of dot probabilities (see e.g. [de Campos and Cozman, 2005]).Consequently, various approaches have been proposed (see [da Rocha et al., 2003, Ide and Cozman, 2008, Tessem, 1992]).We will use our method in Sections 4.3 and 5 to evaluate the performance of inference methods in credential networks with regard to the idea of focusing on specifying only lower limits instead of lower and upper limits, our method is closely related to the work of Finish and Breese [Finish and Breese, 1990].

sections.heading: 3 LOWER BOUND BAYESIAN NETWORKS (LBBN)
sections.text: This section introduces the Lower Bound Bayesian Networks. LBBN offers a novel way of approaching lower boundaries. They provide outer approximations similar to the methods mentioned in the previous section. Unlike these, LBBN does not require the implementation of new algorithms or the extension of predefined data structures. The reason for this is that they are in fact Bayesian standard networks, where only the interpretation of the entries in the CPT is modified.

sections.heading: 4 MAJOR PROPERTIES OF LBBN
sections.text: In this section, we demonstrate two important properties of LBBN: the first is that inference in LBBN yields outer approximations, which is a fundamental justification for our method; the second is that we can even provide accurate solutions if we limit the network to trees with binary variables; and we also comment on the computational complexity of inference in LBBN.

sections.heading: 5.2 RANDOMLY GENERATED NETWORKS
sections.text: To compare our results with those in [Ide and Cozman, 2008], we have randomly generated Bavarian networks with the BNGenerator [Ide, 2004]. Apart from the number of nodes, the number of states and the number of edges, we therefore use the default parameter settings. These parameters were set to create five types of multi-connected networks with 10 nodes. The first 3 types have an edge density of 1.2 (i.e., 12 edges), 1.4 and 1.6, and each network contains only binary nodes. The last 2 types have an edge density of 1.2 and 1.4, respectively, and all their nodes have four states. We have randomly created 10 different network structures for each type, and for each network structure we have 100 instances with randomly selected lower limits. For each instance we have calculated the Mean Square Error (MSE) x. The averages for all structures of a type are set in Table 5.

sections.heading: 6 CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: In this article, we introduced a novel method for propagating lower boundaries at conditional probabilities in Bayesian networks. We focused on prognostic conclusions and proved that our method guarantees to deliver outer approximations that we have proven competitive in terms of accuracy of existing approximations while offering the best computational complexity of all approximations. In the specific case of predictive inference in Bayesian binary variable networks, our method delivers accurate solutions even faster than the currently fastest method available for exact inference in Bayesian binary networks, the 2U algorithm [Ide and Cozman, 2008]. In large networks, the exact propagation is intractable - in our experiments we reached the limit of calculating exact lower and upper boundaries in a network with only 10 nodes and 16 edges - and other approximations are either computationally expensive, limited to specific network structures or both. LBBN provides a viable solution for a large-scale network that we would like to emphasize in any large-scale network.
